subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 13th November 2018: Crude slides for record twelfth session; Brexit text agreed faces domestic obstacles
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP – 13th November 2018: Crude slides for record twelfth session; Brexit text agreed faces domestic obstacles

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries up, dollar down, crude down.

* REAR-VIEW: UK-EU agreed draft on Irish border as part of withdrawal agreement, Kudlow ‘very positive’ talks with China, Italy to stick to 1.5% growth target in 2019, OPEC monthly sees lower demand and higher supply.

* AHEAD: Australian Wage Index, Chinese Industrial Output & Retail Sales, German Flash GDP, UK CPI, EZ Employment and GDP, US CPI, Fed’s Quarles and Powell Speaking.

 

* BREXIT: EU and UK negotiators have agreed a text at a technical level on how to avoid a hard border in NI, which will form part of the Withdrawal Agreement; ministers will get to read the text tonight one-by-one but will not be able to take it away whilst a Cabinet meeting has been scheduled on Wednesday at 14:00 GMT. EU27 envoys will also hold a Brexit meeting late on Wednesday afternoon and similarly Irish PM Varadkar has called for a special cabinet meeting to consider the EU-UK draft agreement. In response, UK opposition parties called for a meaningful vote on any Brexit withdrawal agreement; hard Brexiteers, including Rees-Mogg, were hostile to the announcement since the deal fails to keep the commitments made by PM May, keeping the UK in the customs union, and similarly Former Foreign Minister Boris Johnson announced he will vote against the deal. The Labour party also appeared sceptical with Leader Corbyn claiming that if the technical agreement does not work for the whole country, they will stand against it whilst a Liberal Democrat Leader claimed PM May will not get her Brexit deal through parliament. Following the announcement, diplomatic sources reported that EU leaders could meet for November 25th summit to seal Brexit deal if the technical agreement is approved by the Cabinet on Wednesday. Elsewhere, DUP Deputy Leader Dodds, said it is no surprise that technical talks have ended, stating that the crucial issue is when it comes to Cabinet as the Brexit deal will be a very hard sell, adding the party's concern is that the backstop becomes the default position.

* ITALY: Today was the official EU deadline for a budget re-submission which saw the Italian government confirming it will stick to its 2.4% deficit and to its 1.5% growth target in 2019 draft reply to the EU.   

* TRADE: Optimism continued on this front after White House Economic adviser Kudlow announced to be having ‘very positive' talks with China whilst adding that the benefit of a steady dollar is low inflation. In related comments, an official noted China and the US are engaging in in-depth contact and coming to a mutual understanding after the Trump-Xi call earlier this month.  US National Security Advisor Bolton said the Trump-Xi meeting at G20 will be significant in trade talks although China officials have previously stated they do not expect the trade dispute to be resolved at the G20. In later trade, the SCMP suggested that China's key negotiator is set for US talks on trade.

* SPX -0.15% at 2722%, NDX +0.03% at 6931, DJI -0.40% at 25286. SECTORS: Energy -2.38%, Materials -0.30%, Industrials +0.45%, Cons Discretionary -0.03%, Cons Staples -0.37%, Healthcare -0.68%, Financials +0.54%, Tech +0.09%, Telecoms -0.26%, Utilities +0.35%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Advanced Auto Parts (AAP) surged today after beating EPS and revenue estimates whilst raising full year guidance. General Electric (GE) traded higher after announcing plans to sell USD 4bln of its stake in Baker Hughes (BHGE). Johnson Controls (JCI) was another top mover following its announcement that it will sell its Power Solutions unit. Trade-sensitive stocks Caterpillar (CAT) and United Technologies (UTX) rose on the back of China/US trade talk developments. Apple (AAPL) resisted a rally today after Goldman lowered its estimates for iPhone unit sales, iPhone revenue and its price target for the co. Tyson Foods (TSN) was a bottom mover, affected by its revenue missing estimates. Boeing (BA) dragged down the Dow Jones index today as safety reports determined that it had failed to give the correct pilot preparations for the Lion Air crash. Home Depot (HD) another bottom mover after it gave a negative outlook on demand.

* WTI (Z8) SETTLES USD 4.24 LOWER AT USD 55.69/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 4.65 LOWER AT USD 65.47/BBL. Crude ended the session in the red on Tuesday, extending losses on Trump’s tweet that oil prices should be lower. The downfall was further supported by the monthly OPEC report which saw both 2018 and 2019 oil demand being revised lower from previous estimates whilst supply for 2018 and 2019 was upwardly revised; both elements are adding to the bearish narrative for the complex. A breakdown of the OPEC report saw crude oil output increase mostly in the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Libya and Angola, while production declined in Iran, Venezuela, Kuwait and Nigeria. Elsewhere, the NNPC announced it is looking to increase oil production in 2019 to 1.8mln BPD from its current 1.6mln BPD.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 4 TICKS HIGHER AT 118-16+. The Treasury complex edged higher as European traders left their desks and as US equities began to slide with risk-sentiment deteriorating. Most of the action was concentrated in the front and belly of the curve were yields were lower by c.5bps. The curve was mixed as 2s5s and 2s10s narrowed by c,1bps while 5s30s and 10s30s steepened by c.2bps.

* GBP: Sterling has staged another rebound from sub-1.2850 levels vs the Usd, and 0.8740+ vs the Eur to be precise, to just above 1.3040 at one point after the UK-EU agreed on a technical withdrawal agreement draft; nonetheless most of the moves were pared back after the text (details yet to be released) faced scepticism from lawmakers, with Cable ending the US session around 1.2950. In terms of flows and other specific price moves, Cable held above Monday’s 1.2828 lows in early EU trade and also derived some encouragement from decent UK wage data, but again it was far from plain-sailing or one-way traffic until 1.2900 was reclaimed convincingly and then 1.2950 on the way to a few stops through yesterday’s 1.2965 high and a circa 1.2980 peak. Meanwhile, momentum sellers were reported around 0.8690 in Eur/Gbp following a break of 0.8700 and some underlying bids around 0.8680.

* NZD, EUR, AUD: The next best majors and beneficiaries of a general pull-back in the Greenback, with the antipodean Dollars also drawing support from some tentative signs of mediation between the US and China on trade, with the Kiwi and Aud revisiting 0.6750 and 0.7200+ respectively and the latter just in time or around the NY cut when almost 2bn expiries at the 0.7200 strike rolled off. Meanwhile, the single currency bounced pretty firmly off new 2018 lows vs the Usd not far from big option barriers at 1.1200 and in part on the coat-tails of the Gbp even though Italian budget issues continue to weigh approaching the deadline of EU resubmission of the 2019 fiscal draft. Eur/Usd reached 1.1280 and largely shrugged off Economy Minister Tria’s comments that implied no shaving of the GDP forecast for next year, but perhaps some compensation via an upgraded privatisation programme.

* CHF, JPY: The traditional safe-havens both pared losses as the Usd and DXY retreated (index to 97.229 vs 97.665 at one stage) with the Franc back above 1.0100 and Jpy through 114.00 again – Chf not really reacting to more benign Swiss price data via producer and import metrics.

* CAD: The Loonie lost further ground vs its US counterpart as crude prices continue to capitulate and slide deeper into bear market territory, with the negative streak all set to extend to 12 consecutive sessions. Moreover, the Cad and MXN (latter down through 20.5000) were also ruffled by doubts about the USMCA getting US Congressional approval, with Usd/Cad trading both sides of 1.3250 and multi-month highs.

* NOK: The Norwegian Krona also underperformed vs the Eur and its SEK peer in wake of a miss in mainland Norwegian GDP, with Eur/Nok up near 9.5700 vs Eur/Sek slipping towards 10.2100.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: Gilts and Usd succumb to more downside
content: It’s ostensibly the same dynamic or driver, but what’s good for Brexit in terms of progress towards a deal is bad for UK debt and the FTSE as the Pound climbs on the prospect of a breakthrough. Gilts have extended losses to 54 ticks at 121.85, while the UK’s benchmark stock index has turned red and Cable eclipses post-weekend peaks around 1.2965 with Eur/Gbp enticing momentum offers at 0.8690, according to market contacts before running into some resistance circa 1.1500 in the Gbp/Eur conversion cross (so, 0.8695). Meanwhile, the broader Usd has lost more ground to 97.255 in the DXY vs 97.665 at the high.

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – Goldman Sachs cuts its price target to USD 209 from USD 222; it also lowered its iPhone unit sales, cut FY19 iPhone total units by 6% and cut revenue by 3%. Elsewhere, analysts say that the tech behemoth’s iPhone XR worldwide shipments are estimated to reach 70mln from Q4 2018 to Q3 2019, down from a previous 100mln forecast. Separately, Asian suppliers fell after some component makers warned over weaker than expected results with some suggesting a peak for iPhone sales in several markets. AppleInsider reported the tech giant is considering camera on Apple watch line-up. (DigiTimes/Newswires/AppleInsider)
  • Boeing (BA) – Safety experts have said that the aerospace co. had not disclosed the possible fault which resulted in the Lion Air crash last month. (WSJ)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The Malaysian PM Mohamad said that the investment bank “cheated” Malaysia during its business with the state fund 1MDB, which is facing corruption and laundering probes, as the state aims to gain back more fees from the bank. (Newswires)
  • Intel (INTC) – The chipmaker will launch the Intel XMM 8160 5G modem to assist in the ongoing rollout of 5G connectivity. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – CEO and co-founder of Flipkart Group, Binny Bansal, has resigned following a probe into personal misconduct, according to a regulatory filing. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Assurant (AIZ) – The insurance co. has announced structural reorganisation, in both technology and risk, to help sustainable growth. (Newswires)
  • AT&T (T) – The telecom conglomerate’s CEO Randall Stephenson has criticised the White House over its removal of Jim Acosta’s press credentials, citing that it did not follow the process that it should have. (WSJ)
  • Baker Hughes (BHGE), General Electric (GE) – Baker Hughes and GE announced a series of long -term agreements to maximise value by entering in a JV for the provision of engine services and product management for use in oil and gas and industrial spaces. Together the transactions are expected to maintain GE’s stake in Baker Hughes above 50%. (Newswires)
  • Essex Property Trust (ESS) – The REIT announced that there has been no significant damage to its California portfolio from the wildfires. (Newswires)
  • General Motors (GM) – The automaker is reportedly planning to allow other vehicles, that aren’t GM, on its Maven peer-to-peer car sharing platform by mid-2019. (TechCrunch)
  • Halliburton (HAL) – The oil co.’s CFO Chris Weber is to be replaced by its current VP of Investor Relations, Lance Loeffler, as Weber leaves to find new opportunities. (Newswires)
  • HollyFrontier (HFC) – The co. is to acquire Sonneborn for USD 655mln. (Newswires)
  • Johnson Controls (JCI) – The co. announced agreement to sell its Power Solutions business for USD 13.2bln to Brookfield Business Partners (BBU) and institutional partners, (Newswires) 
  • Kellogg (K) – The cereals co. has announced changes to its organisational structure, it is looking to sell its cookies and fruit snacks unit as well as combine its U.S. Morning Foods, Snacks and Frozen Foods; all to help drive growth. CEO said the co. will not provide FY19 guidance until the budget is approved by the board, he added it is difficult to get business like Kellogg to topline momentum. (Newswires)
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) – The US Pentagon is looking to accelerate the contract for the next and biggest orders of Lockheed’s F-35 jets. (Newswires)
  • Macy’s (M) – The retailer is reportedly planning to reduce how much merchandise it offers as well as cutting staff in efforts to remain financially healthy. (WSJ)
  • Marsh & McLennan (MMC) – The insurance and services firm announced its new unit Marsh-JLT Specialty, where it will combine the special teams from Marsh and Jardine Lloyd Thompson Group. (Newswires)
  • Oil Names (CVX, XOM, COP) – Chevron, ConocoPhillips and Exxon Mobil are reportedly in the first round of bidding for Endeavor Energy Resources, where it could get bids of up to USD 15bln. (Newswires)
  • Wine names (CTZ) – US President Trump tweeted “On Trade, France makes excellent wine, but so does the US The problem is that France makes it very hard for the U.S. to sell its wines into France, and charges big Tariffs, whereas the US makes it easy for French wines, and charges very small Tariffs. Not fair, must change!”. (Twitter)

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – The co.’s YouTube CEO, Susan Wojcicki, said that the EU’s Article 13, which holds websites/co.s responsible for copyright infringements, could cause it to have to block videos. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The online retailer has picked NYC and Crystal City, North Virginia for its new HQ, according to the Washington Post. Elsewhere, the co. has launched its AWS GovCloud Region, its second one in the US. The co. has also announced it will open an AWS data centre in Italy in 2020, the sixth region in Europe. Business Insider reports that Amazon must hand over its Amazon Echo device to authorities investigating a double-murder in 2017. (Washington Post/Business Insider/Newswires)
  • Amgen (AMGN) – The pharma co. released data from its study of cholesterol-treating Repatha, which was positive. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media co. reportedly failed to properly monitor device makers after it gave them access to personal information of its hundreds of millions of users. (NY Times)
  • Shire (SHPG) – The pharma co. has filed a supplemental NDA for extension of the indication of Gattex, a Short Bowel Syndrome treatment. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Brexit "endgame" talk lifts Cable to a 1.29 handle as a deal hangs in the balance; Italian assets underperform ahead of budget re-submission deadline
  • Positive US-China trade rumblings lifting equities but oil extending losses as Presidential jawboning fails
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Italian Budget Resubmission Deadline, ECB’s Stournaras, de Guindos, Fed’s Brainard, Harker, Daly

ASIA

Major Asian equity markets mostly followed suit to the sell-off on Wall St where tech led the declines after Apple shares dropped 5% following an outlook cut by supplier Lumentum Holdings and with energy names hit again after oil posted an 11th consecutive decline. ASX 200 (-1.8%) and Nikkei 225 (-2.1%) weakened from the open with the tech sector the underperformer in the region as another Apple supplier Japan Display reported a loss for H1 and downgraded its outlook. Furthermore, Japanese exporters suffered from recent flows into the JPY and large automakers were pressured after the US Commerce Department submitted a draft recommendation on potential auto tariffs to the White House. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) and Hang Seng (+0.6%) both opened lower although gradually recovered amid hopes for an improvement in US-China trade relations amid reports that US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke by phone on Friday about a deal that could ease trade tensions and with some US officials reportedly expecting China to make a trade offer ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially supported as the broad risk averse tone spurred a flight to safety, but then failed to hold on to the marginal gains as prices mirrored a pullback in T-notes despite stronger 30yr auction results.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9629 (Prev. 6.9476)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke by phone on Friday about a deal that would ease trade tensions. Reports also noted that China officials do not expect to resolve the trade dispute at G20 but are instead hoping for a broad framework deal, while some US officials expect China to make a trade offer ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting and USTR Lighthizer is said to want tariffs to continue to force China into concessions. (WSJ) In related news, China Vice Premier Liu He is to visit the US to pave the way for the Xi-Trump meeting. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li said China's economy faces fresh challenges and is slowing down but long-term fundamentals are good. Premier Li also commented that China aims to persist with deepening reforms through measures including tax cuts, while he added that China hopes to solve trade differences with US through discussions and that both sides will find a solution that meets common interest. (Newswires)

UK/EU/US

UK PM May said Brexit talks are now reaching their "endgame" and that both sides working hard to reach an agreement but added that significant issues still remain and that the government will not accept a deal at any cost. Furthermore, there were reports that UK PM May had rejected the latest draft Brexit deal with the EU as it didn’t provide a clear exit from the customs union if the EU began acting in bad faith in discussions regarding a future trade agreement. (Newswires/The Sun)

DUP's Robinson said it sounds like UK PM May is in the right place regarding Brexit and that the mood has improved but there is still work that remains to be done. (Newswires)

EU sees little chance of a Brexit deal this week as according to the RTE. (Newswires)

Britain's Ambassador to the WTO has said that it is becoming more apparent to WTO members that Britain may leave without a deal (Newswires)

Reports suggested that Italy will maintain their 2019 deficit/GDP target of 2.4% but could alter their 2019 growth target of 1.5%. (Il Sole)

UK Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) Sep 3.2% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 3.1%)

UK Average Weekly Earnings 3M YY Sep 3.0% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 2.7%, Rev. 2.8%)

UK ILO Unemployment Rate Sep 4.1% vs. Exp. 4.0% (Prev. 4.0%)

German ZEW Current Conditions Nov 58.2 vs. Exp. 65.0 (Prev. 70.1)

TRADE

US Commerce Department submitted a draft recommendation on potential auto tariffs to the White House which are undergoing interagency review and are sign of US administration's increasing frustration at EU and Japan over lack of progress on auto trade issues, while the Section 232 recommendations will be discussed at White House trade meeting on Tuesday. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

All major European indices are in the green, with the DAX (+0.6%) out in front, led by the likes of Lufthansa (+2.4%) who are benefiting from lower oil prices and Bayer (+0.3%) who presented an increase in earnings and confirmed their outlook. FTSE MIB (-0.3%) is lagging its peers weighed on by Telecom Italia (-1.4%) who removed their CEO to the dismay of Vivendi (23.9% shareholder). Italian financial names are also softer ahead of today’s budget re-submission deadline. Sectors are predominantly higher with outperformance in Telecoms post-earnings from Vodafone (+9.0%). Energy names lag, in-fitting with price action in the complex. 

Regarding individual equities, BTG (+9.2%) are leading the Euro Stoxx 600 after presenting an increase in half year revenue and operating profit. Elior Group (+8.0%) are off best levels but remain supported by news that they have hired advisors to initiate the sale of their catering business. Babcock (-2.5%) are under scrutiny from the Ministry of Defence over their handling of a contract relating to the UK’s Trident Submarines.

FX

G10 - An almost clear and defining line between the ‘so called’ risk or high beta/yield currencies vs safer-havens, as US-China trade tensions ease somewhat amidst reports of constructive discussions between key officials, while the YUAN also pares some losses with the aid of intervention via local banks overnight (said to have been defending 6.9700 vs the Usd).

Hence, the DXY and broad Dollar are off Monday’s peaks, with the latter only maintaining gains/positive momentum vs the JPY above 114.00 and CHF (to a lesser degree) over 1.0100. However, the index remains underpinned around the 97.500 mark and still poised to build on yesterday’s new ytd high at 97.704 given high levels of ongoing uncertainty and global risks, with only one major chart hurdle seen ahead of 98.000 (97.871 Fib resistance).

NZD/AUD - Outperforming on the aforementioned US-China ‘understanding’, with the Kiwi staying within striking distance of 0.6750 and the latter not far from 0.7200, but perhaps capped by mega option expiry interest at the strike (1.6 bn), while still feeling the adverse effects of bearish cross-positioning as Aud/Nzd inches further below 1.0700.

GBP/EUR/CAD - All holding up relatively well, or at least consolidating off worst levels, with the Pound retesting 1.2900 vs the Greenback and 0.8700 vs the single currency on hopes if not high expectations of a Brexit breakthrough in time before tomorrow’s deadline. Note, some independent support from Sterling via firm UK wage data, but limited. The Eur is just keeping its head above 1.1200 vs the Usd awaiting Italy’s budget resubmission to the EU that is widely expected to reveal a concession or compromise, but no white flag. Option barriers at the big figure are underpinning the headline pair, though by the same token 1 bn expiry interest at 1.1250 are also keeping upside attempts in check. Looking at the Loonie, only fleeting intraday recoveries in oil prices are keeping the commodity unit pressured and it is struggling to stem losses beyond 1.3250.

COMMODITIES

Gold (+0.1%) is marginally up after reaching 16-month highs yesterday. Of note, traders are gathering in Shanghai for Asia Copper Week, as copper prices have fallen by approximately 17% this year, on track for their worst year since 2015. Intra-day, copper and other metals have moved higher following reports that Liu He, China’s top trade negotiator, may visit Washington in preparation for Trump Xi talks.

WTI (-2.2%) and Brent (-2.1%) are in the red after a failed intervention by US President Trump who tweeted that oil prices should be lower, and he hopes Saudi and OPEC do not cut oil production. Note, the monthly OPEC report to be published today at 1115GMT.

OPEC monthly report: OPEC crude production rose 127k bpd in October to average 32.9mln bpd, according to secondary sources. Crude oil output increased mostly in the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Libya and Angola, while production declined in IR Iran, Venezuela, Kuwait and Nigeria. In 2018, oil demand growth is anticipated to increase by 1.5mln bpd, a downward revision of 40k bpd from last month’s projection. For 2019, world oil demand is forecast to grow by 1.29mln bpd, a minor downward adjustment of 70k bpd from the previous month’s assessment

Non-OPEC oil supply in 2018 is expected to grow by 2.31mln bpd, an upward revision of 90k bpd. Non-OPEC oil supply in 2019 is forecast to grow by 2.23mln bpd, a minor upward revision of 120k bpd

FIXED INCOME

Inverse correlations with Italian BTPs are never too far from the surface it seems, and certainly a dynamic that persists while debt markets await the next exchanges between Italy and the EU on 2019 budget divergences. Hence, a further downturn in the 10 year benchmark to just below 121.00 amidst rather tepid auction results, for obvious reasons, has helped Bunds rebound to a new Eurex high, at 160.39, +10 ticks vs -26 ticks at one stage, while Gilts continue to lag on Brexit deal aspirations, albeit paring losses to 9 ticks vs 36 ticks at best, and US Treasuries shadow moves elsewhere ahead of the return of cash participants after Monday’s Veterans Day holiday – futures off worst levels seen overnight, but curve still fractionally steeper.

UK debt and STIR futures braced for Brexit endgame
content: Gilts are extending declines from a brief recovery high of 122.24 vs 122.39 at Monday’s Liffe close, having kicked off at 122.16 and now testing bids just ahead of 122.00 (122.03 trough thus far) as Bunds slip a bit further towards their nearest downside big figure level at 160.03 (-26 ticks) amidst overall bear-steeping in bond markets, partly on more positive vibes from the US and China in terms of trade dialogue, with perhaps some acknowledgement of ECB’s Praet noting that unwinding QE will put some term premium back in to yield curves. However, some of the selling appears pre-emptive, or maybe presumptive is more apt, on the premise that a Brexit breakthrough and solution to the Irish back-stop can be forged before Wednesday’s deadline. Indeed, the Short Sterling strip has flipped from a firmer stance off the open to trade as much as 3 ticks below parity, as attention turns to domestic data and the latest labour report, at least momentarily.

Bunds: somewhat betwixt and between
content: The 10 year German benchmark has lost momentum after paring losses from an early 160.15 Eurex low vs yesterday’s 160.29 close to just 1 tick on further dip-buying ahead of today’s deadline for Italy to present budget revisions to the EU, which will then determine whether Brussels decides to impose EDP measures and effectively veto the 2019 fiscal plan. The timing is particularly pertinent as heavy BTP issuance is due, and Italian debt futures are conceding some ground in the run up having attempted to probe above parity at one stage (within a 121.72-41 range vs their 121.61 previous settlement). However, amidst a broader upturn in risk sentiment on the back of some conciliatory noises from China and the US with regard to trade, Bunds have slipped back to a marginal new 160.10 base. Also scheduled today, Eur4 bn Schatz supply, ZEW’s October survey that may well highlight further growth pangs for Germany and the wider Eurozone economy, and a raft of ECB speakers on top of Praet.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

13th November 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will13e covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Major Asian equity markets mostly followed suit to the sell-off on Wall St where tech led the declines after Apple shares dropped 5% following an outlook cut by supplier Lumentum Holdings and with energy names hit again after oil posted an 11th consecutive decline. ASX 200 (-1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-2.2%) weakened from the open with the tech sector the underperformer in the region as another Apple supplier Japan Display reported a loss for H1 and downgraded its outlook. Furthermore, Japanese exporters suffered from recent flows into the JPY and large automakers were pressured after the US Commerce Department submitted a draft recommendation on potential auto tariffs to the White House. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) both opened lower although mainland stocks gradually recovered amid hopes for an improvement in US-China trade relations amid reports that US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke by phone on Friday about a deal that could ease trade tensions and with some US officials reportedly expecting China to make a trade offer ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially supported as the broad risk averse tone spurred a flight to safety, but then failed to hold on to the marginal gains as prices mirrored a pullback in T-notes despite stronger 30yr auction results.

FTSE

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) – Co. might have made a significant copper discovery in Western Australia, according to reports. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Babcock (BAB LN) – The Co is under additional scrutiny by the Ministry of Defence regarding their handling of a contract to support and refit the UK’s Trident submarines. (FT)

Stobart (STOB LN) – The co.’s Chairman has denied allegations of shareholder vote rigging as he faced ex-CEO Tinkler at High Court. (Guardian)

German Banks – Bundesbank board member, Joachim Wuermeling, told Handelsblatt that he is not worried about the EU stress test results. Adding that German banks are more resilient following the tough reforms after the global financial crisis. (Newswires)

  • UK PM May said Brexit talks are now reaching their "endgame" and that both sides are working hard to reach an agreement but added that significant issues still remain
  • Senior ministers led by UK Brexit Secretary Raab told UK PM May no deal is preferable to the current offer from the EU, according to Buzzfeed
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI (F), UK jobs report, German ZEW, Italian Budget Resubmission Deadline, ECB’s Praet, Lautenschlager, Stournaras, de Guindos, Fed’s Brainard, Harker, Daly, Supply from Italy and Germany

ASIA

Major Asian equity markets mostly followed suit to the sell-off on Wall St where tech led the declines after Apple shares dropped 5% following an outlook cut by supplier Lumentum Holdings and with energy names hit again after oil posted an 11th consecutive decline. ASX 200 (-1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-2.2%) weakened from the open with the tech sector the underperformer in the region as another Apple supplier Japan Display reported a loss for H1 and downgraded its outlook. Furthermore, Japanese exporters suffered from recent flows into the JPY and large automakers were pressured after the US Commerce Department submitted a draft recommendation on potential auto tariffs to the White House. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) both opened lower although mainland stocks gradually recovered amid hopes for an improvement in US-China trade relations amid reports that US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke by phone on Friday about a deal that could ease trade tensions and with some US officials reportedly expecting China to make a trade offer ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially supported as the broad risk averse tone spurred a flight to safety, but then failed to hold on to the marginal gains as prices mirrored a pullback in T-notes despite stronger 30yr auction results.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9629 (Prev. 6.9476)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke by phone on Friday about a deal that would ease trade tensions. Reports also noted that China officials do not expect to resolve the trade dispute at G20 but are instead hoping for a broad framework deal, while some US officials expect China to make a trade offer ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting and USTR Lighthizer is said to want tariffs to continue to force China into concessions. (WSJ) In related news, China Vice Premier Liu He is to visit the US to pave the way for the Xi-Trump meeting. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li said China's economy faces fresh challenges and is slowing down but long-term fundamentals are good. Premier Li also commented that China aims to persist with deepening reforms through measures including tax cuts, while he added that China hopes to solve trade differences with US through discussions and that both sides will find a solution that meets common interest. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May said Brexit talks are now reaching their "endgame" and that both sides working hard to reach an agreement but added that significant issues still remain and that the government will not accept a deal at any cost. Furthermore, there were reports that UK PM May had rejected the latest draft Brexit deal with the EU as it didn’t provide a clear exit from the customs union if the EU began acting in bad faith in discussions regarding a future trade agreement. (Newswires/The Sun)

Senior ministers led by UK Brexit Secretary Raab told UK PM May no deal is preferable to the current offer from the EU and that the current deal will not get through Parliament. (Buzzfeed)

DUP's Robinson said it sounds like UK PM May is in the right place regarding Brexit and that the mood has improved but there is still work that remains to be done. (Newswires)

UK Visa Consumer Spending (Oct) Y/Y -0.2% (Prev. 0.2%); 1st decline in 3 months. (Newswires)

ECB's Lautenschlaeger (Hawk) said she is very much in favour of ending the asset purchase programme, while she also favours designing reinvestments in a flexible way and not too long. (Newswires)

Italy's Deputy PM Salvini said fundamentals of the budget will not change. (Newswires) Furthermore, recent reports suggested that Italy will maintain their 2019 deficit/GDP target of 2.4% but could alter their 2019 growth target of 1.5%. (Il Sole)


FX

In FX markets, the USD held on to most the prior day’s gains although has pulled back from 17-month highs, which provided EUR/USD and GBP/USD some much needed reprieve below the 1.1300 and 1.2900 handles respectively. Elsewhere, JPY-crosses were initially pressured as the risk averse tone continued to spur flows into the safe-haven JPY and commodity-linked currencies began the session subdued following the 11th consecutive drop in oil prices. However, currencies then staged an intraday comeback amid some encouraging trade-related reports and as CNY strengthened on suspected intervention with major state-owned banks seen to have been selling USD against CNY in the onshore spot market at around 6.9700.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures subdued after prices dropped over 2% to briefly below USD 59.00/bbl in the prior session on further Trump jawboning, which was its 11th consecutive loss and longest losing streak on record. Elsewhere, gold and copper prices nursed losses as the USD pulled back from 17-month highs and with the red metal also underpinned by outperformance in its largest consumer amid US-China trade-related hopes.

US President Trump tweeted "Hopefully, Saudi Arabia and OPEC will not be cutting oil production. Oil prices should be much lower based on supply!". (Twitter)

US


Treasury futures were thin, with cash markets closed for Veteran’s Day, leaving the complex to trade off broader risk themes. With the risk-off tone begotten by a stronger USD, weighing on equities, and seeing the VIX rise above 20, the mood was defensive, and as such, Treasuries rose. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 8+ ticks higher at 118-12+.

US Commerce Department submitted a draft recommendation on potential auto tariffs to the White House which are undergoing interagency review and are sign of US administration's increasing frustration at EU and Japan over lack of progress on auto trade issues, while the Section 232 recommendations will be discussed at White House trade meeting on Tuesday. (Newswires)

Fed's Daly (Voter) said she will not be surprised by a December hike and sees at least a couple of hikes in 2019, while she added that the "modal" forecast is for 2-3 hikes over the next period of time and that she is thinking seriously about December rate hike but not definite. Daly also commented that the Fed should head towards neutral and that neutral is uncertain so doesn't see it as a stopping point. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia follows suit to the tech-led rout on Wall St as Apple suppliers downgrade outlooks
content:
Asia equity markets follow suit to the sell-off on Wall St where tech led the declines after Apple shares dropped 5% following an outlook cut by supplier Lumentum Holdings and with energy names hit again after oil posted an 11th consecutive decline. ASX 200 (-1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-3.1%) weakened from the open with the tech sector also underperforming in the region as another Apple supplier Japan Display reported a loss for H1 and downgraded its outlook. Furthermore, Japanese exporters suffered from recent flows into the JPY and large automakers were pressured after the US Commerce Department submitted a draft recommendation on potential auto tariffs to the White House. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (-1.5%) are also lower, but with losses in the mainland stemmed amid hopes for an improvement in US-China trade relations as reports noted that US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He spoke by phone on Friday about a deal that could ease trade tensions and with some US officials reportedly expecting China to make a trade offer ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting.

In FX markets, USD remains firm to hold on to most the prior day’s gains in which the DXY hit a 17-month high and although its major counterparts attempt to nurses, the recovery has been minimal with EUR/USD and GBP/USD firmly below the 1.1300 and 1.2900 handles respectively. JPY-crosses are pressured as the risk averse tone spurs flows into the safe-haven JPY although declines in USD/JPY have been contained by the outperformance of the greenback. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies are subdued following the 11th consecutive drop in oil prices, but with antipodeans off sessions lows as CNY pares some of its losses on suspected intervention with major state-owned banks seen to have been selling USD against CNY in the onshore spot market at around 6.9700.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are marginally higher with prices mildly supported as the risk averse tone spurs a flight to safety, but with upside also capped ahead of a 30yr auction later.
